prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for telling their friend that her being single is because she has five kids by different fathers. 

First, I need to understand the situation. The author's friend has been divorced five times and is still single. The friend has been making hurtful comments about the author's dating life and work. The author, after a lot of time, finally responds by pointing out the friend's situation with the five kids and no child support as a reason she can't find someone. The friend got angry and hung up. Now, mutual friends are blaming the author for being privileged and a bad friend.

So, the key here is whether the author's response was a justified defense against the friend's insults or if it was crossing a line. The friend's comments were about the author's appearance, job, and dating habits, which are personal and possibly mean. The author tried to brush them off but eventually snapped. 

The author's reply was pointing out a factual aspect of the friend's situation that might affect her ability to find a partner. Is calling someone out on their situation considered wrong, even if it's harsh? On one hand, the author was defending themselves after being insulted. On the other hand, the friend's comment about child support and multiple fathers might be a sensitive topic. The author might have overstepped by bringing up something personal that's not the friend's fault entirely. 

Also, the mutual friends are saying the author has "skinny privilege" and is entitled. The author argues that they worked hard. But the friends' reaction suggests they felt the comment was judgmental and not helpful. 

I think the question is whether the author's response was a fair retort or if it was an attack. While the friend was being rude, the author's response might have been too harsh or not the right way to handle it. There might have been a better, more constructive way to address the insults without bringing up the friend's personal situation. 

So, considering all that, the author might be in the wrong because they responded with a personal attack instead of addressing the insults without attacking the friend's circumstances. Even if the friend was being mean, the author's response could be seen as crossing a line. Therefore, the answer is A.
